p: P. curatellifolia extracts did not show cytotoxicity towards the mouse lymphocytes. The water extract showed significant ( p < 0.001) proliferative potential towards the peritoneal cells, and this could be attributed to the presence of several biomolecules within the water extract. The water extract is known to extract compounds such as anthocyanins, starch, polypeptides, saponins, terpenoids, and lectins, which increase T-cell and B-cell proliferation [ 45– 47]. Anthocyanins have been found to protect the thymus and spleen and increased lymphocyte proliferation, suggesting that there is improved immunity [ 48]. Most terpenoids have been shown to increase proliferation of mouse spleen cells and B lymphocytes, while some terpenoids only stimulate the proliferation of B cells but inhibit T-cell proliferation [ 49]. Plant polypeptides have been shown to promote the proliferation of macrophages, TNF- α and IL-6 secretion, TLR2 and TLR4 expression, and increase macrophage phagocytic ability through NO and hydrogen peroxide release [ 50].
